words.def: Body of the insect, toward the posterior of the thorax.
words.name: abdomen

words.def: A chemical employed to kill and control mites and ticks.
words.name: acaricide

words.def: feeding on mites (also refers to parasitoids of mites).
words.name: acariphagous

words.def: Any secondary gland of the glandular system.
words.name: accessory gland

words.def: Small muscular pumps and the veins that accompany them that pump hemolymph into the wings.
words.name: accessory pulsatile organs (APOs)

words.def: Alternative spelling of "acetylcholine".
words.name: acetyl choline

words.def: The two rows of hairs or bristles lying one on either side of the mid-line of the thorax of a true fly.
words.name: acrostichal bristles

words.def: The space within which the concentration of a pheromone or other behaviorally active substance is concentrated enough to generate the required response, remembering that like light and sound pheromones become more dilute the further they radiate out from their source.
words.name: active space

words.def: (Hymenoptera) Any member of a group of families that include the familiar stinging ants, bees, and social and hunting wasp.
words.name: aculeate

words.def: Tapering to a long point.
words.name: acuminate

words.def: A class of insect growth regulators.
words.name: acylurea

words.def: The part of the male genitalia which is inserted into the female during copulation and which carries the sperm into the female. Its shape is often important in separating closely related species.
words.name: adeagus

words.def: Of pupa: the state in which the pupa does not possess movable mandibles, the opposite being decticous.
words.name: adecticous

words.def: A major cell type of insects that stores fat body and reserves nutrients.
words.name: adipocytes

words.def: (adjective): Along the margin.
words.name: admarginal

words.def: The sclerotized terminal portion of the male genital tract that is inserted into the female during insemination.
words.name: aedeagus

words.def: Summer dormancy, entered into when conditions are unfavourable for active life i.e. it is too hot or too dry.
words.name: aestivation

words.def: The regular changing of roles of colony members as they get older.
words.name: age polyethism

words.def: A dilated portion of a trachea.
words.name: air sac

words.def: The middle of three flap-like outgrowths at the base of the wing in various flies.
words.name: alar squama

words.def: muscles along the dorsal diaphragm that may perform circulation.
words.name: alary muscles

words.def: the parthenogenetic winged morph of vividae, specialized for migration.
words.name: alata

words.def: Winged; having wings.
words.name: alate

words.def: (common name). A synthetic insecticide; a chlorinated hydrocarbon of not less than 95 per cent 1,2,3,4,10,10-hexachloro-1,4,4a,5,8,8a-hexahydro-1,4:5,8-dimethanonaphthalene; moderately toxic to mammals, acute oral LD,, for rats 44 mg/kg; phytotoxicity: none when properly formulated, but some crops are sensitive to solvents in certain formulations.
words.name: aldrin

words.def: feeding on algae.
words.name: algophagy

words.def: A term applied to the "open chain" or fatty series of hydrocarbons.
words.name: aliphatic

words.def: Name given to the thorax and propodeum of 'wasp-waisted' hymenopterans.
words.name: alitrunk

words.def: When individuals other than the parent assist in the caring for that parents offspring.
words.name: alloparental

words.def: Two or more forms of a species having essentially separate distributions.
words.name: allopatric

words.def: When two generations are produced within a life cycle each producing individuals of only one sex, either male first and then female or vice versa.
words.name: alternating generations

words.def: Self-destructive. or potentially self-destructive behavior performed for the benefit of others.
words.name: altruistic

words.def: a broad lobe at the proximal posterior margin of the wing stalk of Diptera.Also termed the axillary lobe.
words.name: alula

words.def: The fungus cultivated by wood-boring beetles of the family Scolytidae.
words.name: ambrosia

words.def: The insects which develop without metamorphosis, namely the Protura, Thysanura, and Collembola.
words.name: ametabola

words.def: Compound derived from carboxylic acids by replacing the hydroxyl of the -COOH by the amino group, -NH2-.
words.name: amide

words.def: An organic compound containing nitrogen, derived from ammonia, NH3, by replacing one or more hydrogen atoms by as many hydrocarbon radicals.
words.name: amine

words.def: Organic compounds that contain the amino (NH2) group and the carboxyl (COOH) group. Amino acids are the "building stones" of proteins.
words.name: amino acid

words.def: A colorless alkaline gas, NH3, soluble in water.
words.name: ammonia

words.def: Pertaining to last abdominal segment which bears the anus.
words.name: anal

words.def: The posterior corner of the wing (same as tornus).
words.name: anal angle

words.def: A fold in the inner margin of the hindwing.
words.name: anal fold

words.def: Exposed claspers at the end of the abdomen.
words.name: anal valves

words.def: Infection with Anaplasma, a genus of Sporozoa that infests red blood cells.
words.name: anaplasmosis

words.def: A wilt disease of cucurbits caused solely by the feeding of the squash bug, no parasitic microorganism involved.
words.name: anasa wilt

words.def: (singula = Androconium) In male butterflies, specialised wing scales (often called scent scales) possessing special glands which produce a chemical attractive to females.
words.name: androconia

words.def: Specialised microscopic scales on the wings of male butterflies, believed to be scent scales for attracting the female.
words.name: androconium or androconia (plural)

words.def: Formed in ring-like segments or with ring-like markings.
words.name: annulate

words.def: Deficient in blood quantity or quality.
words.name: anemic

words.def: the lower (anterior) portion of the clypeus of insects.
words.name: anteclypeus

words.def:
The long feelers situated on the head and close to the eyes. They are however not tactile but used for detecting airborne scents and currents.

In Papilionoidea the antennae end in bulging tips called clubs.
In Hesperioidea they have hooked tips and the club is found just before the tip.
In some Lycaenidae like the genus Liphyra the antenna tapers gradually.
words.name: antennae

words.def: Touching with the antenna.
words.name: antennation

words.def: Bearing antennae, as in "antenniferous tubercle".
words.name: antenniferous

words.def: A segment of an antenna. The term antennomere is used in particular when the segments are fairly uniform, as in filiform antennae, but it also may be used in referring to segments of odd sizes, shapes and functions, such as the scape and pedicel. More specific terms may be used where there are distinct antennal regions; for example flagellomeres are the antennomeres comprising the flagellum.
words.name: antennomere

words.def: in front of or after the aforementioned structure.
words.name: anterior

words.def: Small cross-veins at the front of the dragonfly or damselfly wing, between the wing base and the nodus.
words.name: antenodal veins

words.def: feeding on flowers.
words.name: anthophagy

words.def: An association between two or more organisms that is detrimental to one or more of them.
words.name: antibiosis

words.def: A substance antagonistic to the coagulation of blood.
words.name: anticoagulin

words.def: The posterior opening of the digestive tract.
words.name: anus

words.def: The anterior corner of the wing.
words.name: apex / apical area

words.def: The first posterior cell in the wing of Diptera.It is the space between the third and fourth longitudinal vein beyond the anterior crossvein (R5).
words.name: apical cell

words.def: feeding on aphids (and parasitoids of aphids).
words.name: aphidophagy

words.def: Medicinal use of the honey bee or its products.
words.name: apitherapy

words.def: A crossvein between the radius and cubitus near the base of the wing in certain insects.
words.name: arculus

words.def: A small ring of color
words.name: areola

words.def: A pad-like median lobe between the tarsal claws.
words.name: arolium

words.def: Region close to the point of attachment to the thorax.
words.name: base / basal area of wing

words.def: Raised area on the wing surface, circular, ovate, or elongated, which is covered with special scent scales or androconia, found in males of some species. Also called sex mark.
words.name: brand

words.def: feeding on moss.
words.name: bryophagy

words.def: Mainly referring to antennae, but occasionally to other anatomical features such as palps: having a clubbed shape with a relatively long, slender stem, but with an abruptly bulkier, thicker, possibly globular distal head, the capitulum. The term capitate is not strictly distinguished from clavate, but where a distinction is desired, it is that the club of a capitate antenna is abruptly distinct from the shaft, and the head tends to be short and more or less globular. The club of a clavate antenna generally is a more or less tapered thickening, sometimes hardly distinct from the shaft.
words.name: capitate

words.def: The head of a capitate structure, such as a capitate antenna, or of a capitate haltere
words.name: capitulum

words.def: a keel-like elevation (or ridge) on the body-wall of an insect.
words.name: carina

words.def: feeding on fruits and seeds.
words.name: carpophagy

words.def: Markings consisting of rings connected together like a chain.
words.name: catenulate

words.def: Antennae with ringed appearance.
words.name: catenulated antennae

words.def:
The central area surrounded by veins. It can be closed by veins or open.

The vein forming the boundary of the cell along the costal margin is known as the subcostal vein q.v.
The vein forming the lower boundary towards the dorsum is called the median vein.
In the case of butterflies, the cell is closed by a vein connecting the origins of veins 6 to 4 along the top of the cell which is known as discocellular vein.
words.name: cell

words.def: Taxonomically important term used in Diptera identification keys. Part of the schema of wing venation. Also called the posterior cubital cell and often called the anal cell. see File:Phytomyzinae wing veins-1.svg
words.name: cell cup

words.def: feeding on cornified tissues and hair of animals.
words.name: ceratophagy (Also spelled keratophagy)

words.def: (Anatomical feature) the structure defining the neck of the insect.
words.name: cervix

words.def: See Seta.
words.name: chaeta

words.def: An external spine that has a single point. Etymology: Greek chalasa, a tubercle. cf. scolus, which has multiple points.
words.name: chalaza

words.def: See Seta.
words.name: cheta

words.def: Fine hairs along the edges of the wing.
words.name: cilia

words.def: A structure in male insects that is used to hold the female during copulation.
words.name: clasper or clasp

words.def: Same as clavus.
words.name: clava

words.def: Mainly referring to antennae, but occasionally to other anatomical features such as palps: having a clubbed shape with a relatively long, slender stem, but with a bulkier, thicker distal end, the clava. The term clavate is not strictly distinguished from capitate, but in general, where a distinction is desired, the club of a capitate antenna is abruptly distinct, even globular, whereas the club of a clavate antennae is generally a more or less tapered thickening
words.name: clavate

words.def: specifically, in Noctuidae (moths)- an elongate spot or mark extending from the anterior transverse anterior line through the submedian interspace, toward and sometimes to the posterior transverse line.
words.name: claviform stigma

words.def: Same as clavus or club
words.name: clavola

words.def: 1.  The thicker distal end of a clavate anatomical structure such as an antenna. Usually comprising more than one joint. Also called clava, clavola, or club
words.name: clavus

words.def: The popular (possibly to be preferred) name for the clavus of a clavate antenna.
words.name: club

words.def: (Anatomical feature) a sclerite structure below the frons, circumposed by the mandibles and above the labrum.
words.name: clypeus

words.def: feeding on scale insects (and parasitoids of scale insects).
words.name: coccidophagy

words.def: An eye consisting of a large number of individual photoreceptor units or ommatidia (ommatidium, singular).Figure 2 d below
words.name: compound eye

words.def: (largely in Heteroptera and similarly dorsoventrally flattened insects) the edge of the abdomen, containing the connection between the tergite and sternite. May be visible from above in species such as many of the Reduviidae.
words.name: connexivum or connexiva (plural)

words.def: inhabiting feces and consuming mycetes growing inside or cultivating them for feeding.
words.name: copromycetophagy

words.def: feeding on the excrements of animals.
words.name: coprophagy

words.def: The leading edge of the wing.
words.name: costa / costal area

words.def: Taxonomically important term used in Diptera identification keys. Part of the schema of wing venation. weakenings of the costa (one to three in number). They are flexing points for the wings during flight
words.name: costal break

words.def: (Anatomical feature) an anterior suture line of the head between the compound eyes, below the median ocellus.
words.name: coronal suture

words.def: first leg segment, between body and trochanter.
words.name: coxa

words.def:
A general term for a structure by which an object hangs (from Greek language kremastos, meaning "hung up"); for example in entomology:
in some Lepidoptera, including most butterflies, the pupa attaches to a surface by the cremaster, a structure at the tip of the pupal abdomen. The cremaster is the homologue of the anal plate of the caterpillar. It takes various forms in different species, ranging from a simple point, to various arrangements of hooks that catch Velcro-like in a silken pad that the caterpillar spins on the surface before it enters the prepupal phase.
words.name: cremaster

words.def: Adjective = scalloped. Describes the outer edge of a wing that is convex at the end of each vein and concave in between.
words.name: crenulate

words.def: Noun = wedge. Particularly in mirid bugs, a wedge-shaped section of the hemelytra (forewings), located at the apex of the thick, leathery part of the wings.
words.name: cuneus

words.def: Functional mandibles present in pupal state.
words.name: decticous

words.def: feeding on trees.
words.name: dendrophagy

words.def: As for crenulate but with the projections at the end of each wing being toothlike.
words.name: dentate

words.def: feeding on ground remains of plants and animals.
words.name: detritophagy

words.def: The central band passing through the cell.
words.name: disc / discal area

words.def: In damselflies (Zygoptera) a basal quadrangular cell in the wing venation, which is delimited by veins MA (anterior side), MP (posterior side), MAb (distal side) and the arculus (basal side).
words.name: discoidal cell

words.def: The trailing edge or hind-margin of the wing, extending from the base to the tornus. Dorsal alternately, also refers to the back, i.e. the upper part of the body, from above.
words.name: dorsum / dorsal area

words.def: (Anatomical feature) having exterior mouthparts, or exposed. A defining feature of insects.
words.name: ectognathous

words.def: (Anatomical feature) either a bristle-like or pad-like structure between the tarsal claws of various insects, notably Diptera.
words.name: empodium

words.def: the immuno response by plasmatocytes to the presence of parasitoid egg or larvae which results in the formation of a multilayered capsule that causes the parasitoid to sufficate or starve.
words.name: encapsulation

words.def: feeding on dead arthropods.
words.name: entomonecrophagy

words.def: feeding on other insects.
words.name: entomophagy

words.def: (Anatomical feature) the top of the anterior structure of the head, or forehead.
words.name: epicranius

words.def: (Anatomical feature) a plate or projection dorsal to the anus in certain insects, generally on abdominal segment X or XI. For example in Archaeognatha and Zygentoma it takes the form of a long, rearwardly directed organ resembling the two cerci that flank it. In the Odonata epiprocts have various functions, both in larvae, in which they may have respiratory roles, and in adults, in which they may have reproductive roles. Not all epiprocts in all insect species are homologous. Note that the term is used in other groups than insects as well, for instance Myriapoda.
words.name: epiproct

words.def: The palpi when vertical, i.e. the axis of the palpi is at right angles to the axis of the body.
words.name: erect

words.def: Pupae with their legs and other appendages free and extended.
words.name: exarate

words.def: Spots resembling mammalian eyes. Can also refer to simple eyes.
words.name: eyespots or ocelli

words.def: the area between the base of antennae, oral margin, eyes and cheeks (gena). See figure 3.
words.name: face

words.def: A color pattern with a broad band.
words.name: fascia (plural fasciae)

words.def: third leg segment, between trochanter and tibia.
words.name: femur

words.def: an antennomere comprising part of the flagellum.
words.name: flagellomere

words.def: the part of the antenna distal to the pedicel composed of one or more segments, called flagellomeres.
words.name: flagellum

words.def: (Anatomical feature) the posterior opening of the head capsule, covered by the cervix.
words.name: foramen magnum

words.def: (Anatomical feature) the pair of wings of a four-winged insect closest to the head.
words.name: forewing

words.def: (Anatomical feature) The frontal area of an insect's head. It covers the upper part of the face above the clypeus and below and between the antennae. It supports the pharyngeal dilator muscles and usually bears an ocellus.
words.name: frons

words.def: (Anatomical feature) suture lines that meet with the coroanl sutures to form an inverted Y.
words.name: frontal sutures

words.def: (Anatomical feature) the area below the compound eyes, the insect equivalent to human cheeks.
words.name: gena

words.def: Elbowed. From the Latin for a bended knee, referring to an organ of a type not always expected to be kinked, but having a definite angular bend or hinge. In entomology the term typically refers to an elbowed antenna. For instance, many species of Hemiptera, Coleoptera, and Hymenoptera have markedly geniculate antennae
words.name: geniculate

words.def: a strand of silk used to prop up the pupa. Found especially in the Papilionidae.
words.name: girdle

words.def: smooth, without hairs or scales.
words.name: glabrous

words.def: ventral head sclerite which supports the submentum
words.name: gula

words.def: feeding on worms classified with helminths (including parasitoids of helminths).
words.name: helminthophagy

words.def: the interior of the insects anatomy, including all organs and hemocyte.
words.name: hemocoel

words.def: a fluid in the circulatory system of insects containing nutrients, fat, water, etc.
words.name: hemocyte or haemolymph

words.def: feeding on blood.
words.name: hemophagy

words.def: (Anatomical feature) the pair of wings of a four-winged insect farthest from the head.
words.name: hindwing

words.def: transparent, like glass.
words.name: hyaline

words.def: mode of life: living in the thin film of water on wet rocks.
words.name: hygropetric

words.def: having mouthparts that are ventrad of a vertically oriented head, or having an "under bit".
words.name: hypognathous

words.def: Mouthpart. A tonguelike lobe on the floor of the mouth.
words.name: hypopharynx

words.def: a form of parasitism where the parasitoid paralyzes or leaves the host unable to continue development at oviposition.
words.name: idiobiont

words.def: (plural is usually imagines) The final, or adult, stage in metamorphosis.
words.name: imago

words.def: The region between adjacent veins.
words.name: interspace

words.def: Old term used usually to indicate a sprinkling of scales interspersed among scales typically of a different color.
words.name: irrorated or irroration

words.def: feeding on cornified tissues and hair of animals.
words.name: keratophagy (Also spelt ceratophagy)

words.def: A form of parasitism where the parasitoid lives inside the host while allowing it to live after oviposition.
words.name: koinobiont

words.def: Mouthpart forming the lower lip. Bears the labial palps.
words.name: labium

words.def: (Anatomical feature) the anterior structure below the clypeus covering some of the mouthparts, sometimes called the "upper lip".
words.name: labrum

words.def: feeding on lichens.
words.name: lichenophagy

words.def: (Anatomical feature) the suture lines where the integument will split to allow for molting.
words.name: lines of weakness

words.def: A body area or marking roughly in the shape of a crescent.
words.name: lunule

words.def: large bristles and scales.[1]
words.name: macrochaete

words.def: Having long or large elytra, as long, or longer than the abdomen.
words.name: macropterous

words.def: feeding on mollusks (and parasitoids of mollusks).
words.name: malacophagy

words.def: Mouthpart. The maxillae are paired and arranged behind the mandibles. May bear palps. See Figures 1 and 3.
words.name: maxilla

words.def: a small triangular opaque region at the base of the hindwing in some dragonflies.
words.name: membranule

words.def: the middle segment of the thorax, between the prothorax and the metathorax.
words.name: mesothorax

words.def: small metallic-looking spots commonly found on the wings of Riodinidae.
words.name: metalmarks

words.def: The third and last segment of the thorax after the mesothorax.
words.name: metathorax

words.def: Having short elytra, shorter than the abdomen.
words.name: micropterous

words.def: feeding on myxomycetes fungus.
words.name: mixomycetophagy

words.def: Infestation of fly larvae on or in a vertebrate host.
words.name: myiasis

words.def: feeding on fungus.
words.name: mycetophagy

words.def: consuming of dead animals and their remains.
words.name: necrophagy

words.def: Older term for vein. adnervural refers to instance lines running adjacent and alongside the veins.
words.name: nervure

words.def: (of Odonata ) A prominent cross-vein near the center of the leading edge of a wing.
words.name: nodus

words.def: Appendages fused or glued to the body.
words.name: obtect

words.def: (Anatomical feature) the structure that defines the occiput. See Figure 1 (below).
words.name: occipital suture

words.def: (Anatomical feature) the region posterior to the vertex on the head. See Figure 2 (below).
words.name: occiput (insect)

words.def: (Anatomical feature) the structure of the head containing the ocelli.
words.name: ocular structure

words.def: A woodlouse shaped, flattened platyform appearance of a larva.[2]
words.name: onisciform

words.def: feeding on eggs.
words.name: oophagy

words.def: with receding mouthparts, or having mouthparts that slope backward or face backward.
words.name: opisthognathous

words.def: a marking placed between the reniform stigma and the thorax, usually circular in shape.
words.name: orbicular stigma

words.def: fleshy structure on some larvae, often discharging odorous chemicals.
words.name: osmeterium

words.def: the act of laying eggs.
words.name: oviposition

words.def: if part of the ovipositor is visible when not in action, then the basal visible portion, typically tubular, is the oviscape. For examples, see females of many Tephritidae and Pyrgotidae (cf scape).
words.name: oviscape

words.def: structure by which many insects place their eggs, sometimes by piercing or slitting the host or substrate in which she lays the eggs. The structure may be tubular and may have valves.
words.name: ovipositor

words.def: a stink gland or repugnatorial gland, from which an animal such as an insect or Myriapod may release a foul-smelling liquid or gas for defence
words.name: ozadene

words.def: the opening of an ozadene, a stink gland or repugnatorial gland
words.name: ozopore

words.def: feeding on pollen.
words.name: palynophagy

words.def: In parasitism, the participant that benefits, rather than the one that is being parasitized.
words.name: parasitoid

words.def: the second segment ( antennomere) of the antenna. See figure 3.
words.name: pedicel

words.def: Comparatively large processes that originate from below the head and curve forward in front of the face that sometimes appear like a beak. lp on the figure right.
words.name: pedipalp (or labial palpi or palpi)

words.def: feeding on bark.[3][4][5]
words.name: phloeophagy

words.def: feeding on leaves.
words.name: phyllophagy

words.def: feeding on plants.
words.name: phytophagy

words.def: A sclerotised region on the lateral part of an insect segment, bearing the spiracle, and separating and connecting the tergite and the sternite (compare: pulmonarium).
words.name: pleurite

words.def: feeding on pollen.
words.name: pollinophagy

words.def: The palpi when horizontally projecting in front of the face. In this case, the axis of the palpi is parallel to the axis of the body.
words.name: porrect

words.def: the upper (proximal) portion of the clypeus of insects.
words.name: postclypeus

words.def: in a position behind or below the aforementioned.
words.name: posterior

words.def: (Anatomical feature) the structure posterior to the occipital suture, surrounding foramen magnum or occipital magnum.
words.name: postoccipital suture

words.def: tubular feeding and sucking organ.
words.name: proboscis

words.def: Directed or leaning forward, such as in bristles in particular locations of insects' heads.
words.name: proclinate

words.def: having mouth parts dorsad of a dorsally oriented head, or "over bite".
words.name: prognathous

words.def: fleshy leg like structures arising from the abdominal segments of caterpillars. These prolegs have crochets or curved hooks.
words.name: proleg

words.def: The first segment on the thorax anterior to the mesothorax.
words.name: prothorax

words.def: The prominent cell, usually opaque and coloured, near the tip of each wing of the Odonata, on the anterior margin; also, more loosely, called stigma.
words.name: pterostigma (plural pterostigmata)

words.def: The meso- and metathorax of winged insects, that carries the two pairs of wings.
words.name: pterothorax

words.def: A membranous instead of a sclerotised connection or pleurite between the abdominal tergites and sternites of certain groups of insects; in such species the pulmonaria bear the spiracles. The term also refers to an abdomen in which the connection between the tergal and sternal sclerites takes the form of a pulmonarial membrane. (Compare: pleurite)
words.name: pulmonarium (plural pulmonaria)

words.def: an oval or kidney-shaped mark on the forewing at the disc (Lepidoptera)
words.name: reniform stigma

words.def: (generally in combination as in: "repugnatorial glands"): defensive, or "fighting back", in particular as applied to an ozadene, a gland that can release irritant, poisonous, alarming or distasteful fluids or gases when an organism is under threat. Examples of repugnatorial glands include the osmeterium of larvae of the Papilionidae, the stink glands of most Heteroptera, the ozadenes of Opiliones, the odoriferous glands of Diplopoda, and others.
words.name: repugnatorial

words.def: feeding on rhizomes.
words.name: rhizophagy

words.def: adapted for leaping or jumping.
words.name: saltatorial

words.def: feeding on dead bodies of vertebrates.
words.name: sarconecrophagy

words.def: inhabiting decaying matter and consuming mycetes growing inside or cultivating them for feeding.
words.name: sapromycetophagy

words.def: feeding on decaying organic matter.
words.name: saprophagy

words.def: the proximal segment ( antennomere) of the antenna. See Figure 3.
words.name: scape

words.def: feeding on ground remains of plants and animals.
words.name: schisophagy

words.def: An external spine having multiple points. Etymology: Greek skolos, a prickle. cf. chalaza. plural: scoli
words.name: scolus

words.def: Latin term meaning "in the sense of".
words.name: sensu

words.def: The process of animals accumulating poisonous compounds from the food they are eating in order to become poisonous themselves for their predators. Pyrrolizidine alkaloid sequestration refers to the sequestration of one such class of poisonous compounds.
words.name: sequestering

words.def: A stiff chitinous or sclerotised hair or bristle. Also chaeta, cheta
words.name: seta

words.def:
being like or having the nature of a seta or of setae
setose
words.name: setaceous

words.def: bearing, or covered in setae.
words.name: setose

words.def: Diminutive of seta. A small chitinous hair or bristle.
words.name: setula

words.def: bearing, or covered in setulae.
words.name: setulose

words.def: Respiratory openings on the thorax and abdomen that allow air to enter the trachea.
words.name: spiracle

words.def: feeding on mycet spores.
words.name: sporophagy

words.def: Prominent cells on the forewings of some moths. Their size, shape and colour can be useful in identifying some species. Also the prominent cell, usually opaque and coloured, near the tip of each wing of the Odonata, on the anterior margin; also called pterostigma.
words.name: stigma (plural stigmata)

words.def: Patterns with thin lines.
words.name: strigae

words.def: Taxonomically important term used in Diptera identification keys. Part of the schema of wing venation.The second longitudinal wing vein, posterior to the costa. It may reach the costa, fade before the costa or join R1 before it reaches the costa. see [2] (= auxiliary vein of many authors)
words.name: subcosta

words.def: (Anatomical feature) suture lines below the gena.
words.name: subgenal suture

words.def: a shared ancestral ("primitive") character state that cannot be used to demonstrate the monophyly of a group.
words.name: symplesiomorphy

words.def: a shared homologous and derived character state (evolutionary novelty) that demonstrates the monophyly of a group (clade).
words.name: synapomorphy

words.def: a form of reproduction in which the female continues to produce and to mature eggs throughout its life cycle.
words.name: synovigenic

words.def: fifth (last) leg segment, the part that touches the walking surface.
words.name: tarsus (plural tarsi)

words.def: The edge of the wing most distant from the body.
words.name: termen

words.def: Along the margin.
words.name: terminal and marginal

words.def: The part of the body that lies between the head and the abdomen. It has three parts - prothorax, mesothorax and metathorax.
words.name: thorax

words.def: fourth leg segment, between femur and tarsus.
words.name: tibia

words.def: a pubescence consisting of soft, entangled hairs pressed close to the surface of the integument.
words.name: tomentum

words.def: The posterior corner of the wing.
words.name: tornus / tornal area

words.def: second leg segment, between coxa and femur.
words.name: trochanter

words.def: The mouthparts of Arthropoda such as insects; typically labrum, mandible, maxilla, labium.
words.name: trophi

words.def: The singular form of trophi (rarely used).
words.name: trophus

words.def: hook-like, as in the mouthparts of many fly larvae. (also uncinate)
words.name: uncate

words.def: hook-like, as in the mouthparts of many fly larvae. (also uncate)
words.name: uncinate

words.def: pretarsus the claws at the tip of most insect pretarsi.
words.name: unguis (plural ungues)

words.def: a segment or part of the abdomen in insects.
words.name: urite

words.def: plate on the dorsal (upper) surface of an abdominal segment in insects.
words.name: urotergite

words.def: One of several appendages that combine to form the ovipositor of a typical female insect.
words.name: valve

words.def: In female Heteroptera valvifers comprise four blades, one pair on each of abdominal segments 8 and 9. They articulate with the paratergites and bear their corresponding valvulae.
words.name: valvifer

words.def: One of four blades in a female Hemipteran with a laciniate type of ovipositor, that combine to form the ovipositing mechanism.
words.name: valvula

words.def: Hollow structures formed from the coupling of the upper and lower walls of the wing. They provide both rigidity and flexibility to the wing. (See also Comstock-Needham system.)
words.name: vein

words.def: (Anatomical feature) The apex of the head, usually containing ocelli.
words.name: vertex

words.def: covered with numerous thick-set, slender projections resembling short hairs.
words.name: villose

words.def: inhabiting wood and consuming mycetes growing in wood or cultivating them for feeding.
words.name: xylomycetophagy

words.def: feeding on wood.
words.name: xylophagy

words.def: feeding on fungus found on other animals.
words.name: zoomycetophagy

words.def: feeding on animals, and/or animal matter.
words.name: zoophagy
